titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. This was the day appointed for the attendance of John Smith of Ohio, and for the consideration of the Report in his case— His Counsel Mr: Key, and also Mr: Harper, who was now admitted as such appeared and requested further time— A number of Depositions received, enclosed to the Secretary of the Senate, were referr’d to a select Committee— Mr: Giles made a second Speech on his penal bill— Nearly three hours long. Adjourn’d about 3. O’Clock.— In the Evening I attended with our family a Ball at Mr: Erskine’s.

2. Mr: G. W. Campbell, and Mr: Gardenier this morning fought their duel, in which the latter was badly, if not mortally wounded.— Mr: Campbell afterwards took his seat in the House of Representatives, as if nothing had happened— Mr: White did not make his appearance in Senate, and Mr: Bayard after attending a few minutes went out to visit his unfortunate friend— The Senate was engaged all the morning upon the bill for raising 6000 men, the details of which were discussed, and some Amendments to the Bill were adopted— Mr: R. Derby of Boston came after dinner, and spent part of the Evening here— He has a taste for music; and sung with the Ladies, much to my gratification— A complaint in my eyes prevents me from writing, by candle-light, as I could wish.

3. The Committee on the third Embargo-Bill—Smith of Maryland, Hillhouse and myself met, and discuss’d some Amendments— Adjourn’d to meet again to-morrow— In Senate The Bill for raising six thousand additional men, was resumed, further considered, and recommitted— I Dined with Mr: R. Smith the Secretary of the Navy— Judges Marshall,
Johnson and Livingston—Mr: Giles—several members of the House of Representatives, and several naval Officers were there— General Smith his lady and daughter came after dinner— I had some conversation with Mr: Nicholas, who appeared very anxious respecting the rumours in circulation that our Administration is under french influence— He asked me to speak to the President on the subject. I spent part of the Evening at Mr: Boyd’s— Mr: Robinson the Senator from Vermont also hinted to me this morning a wish that I would call on the President.

4. The Committee on the third Embargo-Bill met, and agreed on some Amendments which the chairman reported— The Committee on the Bill for raising 6000 men also met and reported several Amendments— The Chairman Mr: Giles was by illness unable to attend— The Senate adjourned early, and I knew not upon what they were engaged; for Mr: Nicholas asked for some conversation with me, in the Committee-Room of the Senate; to which we accordingly retired— He then express’d much anxiety respecting the present State of Affairs, and particularly respecting the rumours of French influence as predominating in the Administration— He was very solicitous that they should be refuted; declared they were entirely destitute of truth; and requested me to ask the President himself, who would be pleased to give me a direct Answer on the subject— I told him that the jealousies and suspicions among my friends and neighbours were founded on a variety of circumstances, which gave them colour, and which were not easily susceptible of refutation— I then told him of a letter I had seen early last Summer from the Governor of Nova-Scotia, asserting that the British Government were inform’d of a plan determined upon by France, to conquer the British Provinces on this Continent, and form a Monarchy of them under General Moreau— And at the same time to introduce a more monarchical Government in these States— All which was to be effected by means of a War between this Country and Great Britain— This Story, combined with many recent occurrences was a source of distrust which could not without difficulty be removed— He disclaimed all knowledge or belief of such a plan, and supposed its object to be merely a British device to divide and distract us— We had a conversation of perhaps a couple of hours; he asked me whether he might make use of the information I had given him; to which I assented, so far as that no names might be implicated. Sometime afterwards Mr: Pope came to me, and asked me to introduce a Bill to continue the Act of 3. March 1805, and the President’s Proclamation under it— He said the House would not pass the Bill which we had pass’d early in the Session, to reinforce that Act— For they would not arm the frigates, and agree to the Torpedo system; but they wanted the remainder of the Bill— I told him that the house might strike out then what they disliked; or introduce a Bill themselves to continue the Act— It would be inconsistent in us, and particularly in me, to bring forward such a Bill, while the other was before the House— To which he assented— Mr: and Mrs: Boyd pass’d the Evening with us— Mr: Hellen, Mr: Boyd and myself, went for a half an hour to the Methodist Church; where a very miserable preacher was holding forth to a house so crowded that we could scarcely get within the doors— We made a short stay.

5. I called this morning, on the suggestion of Mr: Robinson and Mr: Nicholas, and left a card at the President’s—he was engaged with the heads of Departments so that I could not see him as I wished— I called also at the Treasury Office to see the Secretary, Mr: Gallatin, to shew him the Bill I have reported for issuing certain debentures, which is now at the second reading, and to be taken up next Tuesday— Mr: Gallatin however being with the President I did not see him— I left a copy of the Bill with Mr: Sheldon, to put into his hands; with a request that he would examine it, and propose such alterations or Amendments as he might think proper— I likewise called at Mr: Rose’s lodgings, but he was not at home— I dined at Mr: Boyd’s, and spent the Evening, with our Ladies at Genl: Mason’s in Georgetown— The party was numerous, and somewhat dull— I found a partial relief in Cards, with Mr: Teacle, Mr: Brent & Dr: Worthington.

6. I went to the Methodist Church at Georgetown, and heard the bishop or principal elder of all the methodist Societies, Asbury— His doctrines were more enthusiastic than his manner— The Church was very much crowded, and I found it difficult to procure a seat— I paid a visit to Coll: Williams— Continued answering letters as long as day-light lasted, but I could not write in the Evening.— Mrs: Boyd dined, and with her husband pass’d the Evening here.

7. The question was at last taken in the Senate, on striking out the first Section of Mr: Giles’s treason-bill, 17. to 15. against striking out— The bill was then recommitted, and two new members, Mr: Pope and Mr: Franklin, added to the Committee— The
third Embargo-bill pass’d as amended to the third reading;—without opposition— Mr: Smith of Maryland wished to have it read the third time this day; which was negatived by Mr: Pickering— The Amendment to the Bill from the house, for remitting the duties on the monument imported by the naval Officers was agreed to, by yeas and nays 18 to 12. Little other business done.— Mr: Casamajor the younger spent the Evening with us below.— We had music.

8. Several bills were pass’d in Senate, through their various and respective Stages— Among them the Embargo-bill, and the monument bill— There was no debate— The debenture bill; reported by me was considered at the second reading; and after some observations from me postponed, untill to-morrow, for the attendance of Mr: Bradley who opposed it. Adjourned between one and two— Met afterwards with Mr: Anderson, on the Committee to examine the papers forwarded by Elias Glover— They are voluminous, and tedious— There was in the Evening a party at Mr: Erskine’s— The last for the Season— The ladies of our house attended it; excepting my wife— I spent the Evening, writing.

9. Met the Library-Committee this morning at ten, in the Library— The Members, Mitchell, Adams, Giles of the Senate, and Dana, J. Clay, and Nicholas of the House— Several orders were taken, for placing the appropriation of this year in the hands of the agent, and for the payment of sundry bills— Mr: Dana, was chosen Clerk— Adjourned to receive the report of the agent, and for the Chairman to prepare the annual report.— In Senate the bill for raising 6000 men pass’d— Our Amendment to the Monument Bill was rejected by the House, and the Senate receded— My debenture Bill gave rise to a debate of three hours after which it was recommitted, with the addition of two members, Anderson and Bayard— We spent the Evening & supp’d at Mr: Boyd’s.

10. I called this morning on the Secretary of the Navy, with the application from Samuel Parker, for an appointment in the Navy— Mr: Smith took the letter, and said he would enquire as to his character— The Senate were in Session when I reached the Capitol— In Executive business, reports were made from Committees, in favour of nominations of R. Williams, as Governor of the Mississippi Territory, which was confirmed after a representation from Mr: Smith of Maryland, chairman of the Committee of the complaints against Mr: Williams, which were principally for appointing federalists to Office— Report also was made against the nomination of W. Hull, as Governor of the Michigan Territory; and the papers submitted— The question was postponed. After the adjournment I went into the House of Representatives, who were engaged upon our Georgia Light-House-Bill— Mr: Cook came and advised with me on the Presidential Election— He says Mr: Masters of New-York tells him that the understanding between the New-York and Virginia protesters is to support Clinton for President, and Monroe for Vice-President— I gave him advice as he desired— Evening at home.

11. Met the Committee on the debenture-bill. Mr: Bayard produced an Amendment, which was in substance a new Bill— With some slight alterations to which Mr: Bayard was very averse, the majority agreed to report this Amendment, but still subject to the decided opposition of Mr: Bradley, and Mr: Anderson— The Marine Militia-Bill was debated as in Committee of the whole, at the second reading, and after proposed amendments by Mr: Bradley, was postponed to the first Monday in December next on the motion of Mr: Bayard.— I took no part in the discussion and voted for the postponement— In Executive business the Cherokee Treaty was referr’d to a select Committee— Adjourn’d about 2. I went into the House of Representatives, where they were debating a Bill to authorise Courts of Enquiry and Courts Martial to compel the attendance of witnesses— Heard Mr: Rowan & Mr: Love, on the two sides of the question— Evening at home—writing.

12. Met this morning the Committee on Mr: Giles’s penal bill— To the five former members two new ones are added. Mr: Pope and Mr: Franklin— It was agreed after some discussion to strike out the two Treason sections, and various other amendments were agreed to. The Committee are to meet again on Monday morning, before deciding upon the report— After the Committee adjourned, I had some conversation with Mr: Giles, in which I communicated to him the same information which I had last week given to Mr: Nicholas— Mr: Giles desired me to give it to Mr: Jefferson— I enquired of Mr: Coles whether the President would probably be disengaged this Evening; but he said he would have Company to dine, and be detained perhaps untill late.
In the Evening, I received a letter from Jos: Hall—in great alarm at the state of affairs— Also an anonymous letter from Cincinnati containing great commendations upon the report in the case of John Smith.— Mr: Boyd called upon us with Mr: Fry, and we went with him to his house and supp’d.

13. Heard Mr: Sayres at Georgetown— But he was so unwell that he could not get through his discourse, and was obliged to finish somewhat abruptly— I received an anonymous letter, apparently from Boston, but without Post-mark— I spent the remainder of the day at home— Mr: & Mrs: Boyd dined here— He went home early in the Evening unwell.— Mr: Casamajor the younger, pass’d the latter part of the Evening and supp’d here.

14. Met the Committee on Mr: Giles’s penal bill at ten this morning— I presented a new Section to be substituted for one in the Bill; which was agreed to, and the chairman authorised to report— Met also the Committee on the Cherokee Treaty— The Chairman Mr: Anderson, and Mr: Tiffin agreed to report a ratification, to which I did not assent— Thinking that some enquiry should first be made, into the merits of the remonstrance from several of the tribe against this Treaty. In Senate, the bill concerning Contracts was under consideration— Genl: Smith of Maryland offered an Amendment, and the bill was laid over untill to-morrow.— Some other Bills were also postponed— In Executive business, the nomination of Governor Hull was further delayed; and also that of Reuben Atwater (Mr: Bradley’s brother in Law) as Secretary of the Territory of Michigan; on a question whether it ought to be confirmed untill the late Secretary Stanley Griswold has been removed— After the adjournment I went to Georgetown— Evening at home.

15. The consideration of the Report in the case of Mr: Smith of Ohio was this day resumed, and his counsel moved for further time, untill the first Monday in April; which after some debate was negatived by yeas and nays 17 to 15— At the request of his Council the subject was then postponed untill to-morrow; they not having their papers ready— The debenture Bill as amended pass’d to the third reading, Mr: Bradley declaring his determination to oppose its final passage— In Executive business the Cherokee Treaty was considered, and postponed untill the next Session— Adjourned about 3.— In the Evening I called upon the President, and gave him the information respecting the letter from the Governor of Nova-Scotia which I saw last Summer— He assured me there had never been any negotiation on the subject with France, and that France had never intimated a wish that we should join her in the War— He appears convinced however that the British Government do not now intend immediate War with us— I pass’d the remainder of the Evening at Mr: Boyd’s, where I found Mr: Buchanan.

16. The Counsel of Mr: Smith of Ohio this morning renewed their application for further postponement of the Report, untill the 1st: of next month, which after some debate was carried by yeas and nays 17 to 15— The penal bill was taken up; and some debate upon it had, untill the adjournment— Mr: Buchanan, with Mr: Boyd and family dined & pass’d the Evening with us— I received another anonymous letter, dated at Boston; and also Mr: Pickering’s printed letter to Governor Sullivan.

17. Met this morning the Committee on the Bill concerning Courts Martial and Courts of Inquiry.— Mr: Giles and Mr: Gregg, are the other members— We discuss’d the general principle of the Bill, but did not examine the detail— Adjourned to meet again to-morrow. The principal occupation of the Senate was on the penal bill, in which some further progress was made; and the discussion closed on the second reading— I introduced Mr: Buchanan to Mr: Anderson, Mr: Crawford, and Mr: Milledge; he wished to make enquiries concerning some lands in Tennessee and Georgia— We spent the Evening with Genl: Smith of Maryland, who has his family here— Company not very large—

18. Committee on the Court-Martial Bill— Made further progress, without coming to a decision— To meet again to-morrow Morning— Senate continued in Session untill past 4. O’Clock— Penal Bill further discuss’d— In Executive business confirmed the nomination of Reuben Atwater, Secretary of the Michigan Territory— Read the papers relative to the conduct of Governor Hull—nothing substantial appears against him in them— I spent the Evening at home—busily engaged— I must write, and have no time but the Evening left me— I know not but it may cost me my eyes; but I cannot remain silent.

19. The Senate yesterday adjourned over to Monday— But I attended this day on two Committees— The first upon Mr: Giles’s Habeas Corpus resolution— Mr: Giles, Mr: Bradley, Mr: Anderson and myself were there— Mr: Crawford the other member did not attend— After a desultory discussion, it was finally determined, that the Chairman should draw a Bill, to present at the next meeting of the Committee; to be founded on the English Statute of 31. Charles 2.— The other Committee was on the Court-Martial Bill—we agreed upon several amendments to be reported on Monday— I went into the House of Representatives, and heard them debating on the army Bill— They soon adjourned— Sloan, the Quaker member from New-Jersey came and said he was now for George Clinton as President and James Monroe for Vice-President— Though he had voted for Mr: Madison at the meeting— William Duane he said was coming out in the Aurora, very strong for Madison— But Clinton and Monroe would be elected.— I spent the Evening at home, writing. As I went to the Capitol this morning, I met Mr: Quincy, who turn’d about, and walked back with me— Mr: Livermore, after making yesterday a motion in the House of Representatives to raise the Embargo, and suspend intercourse with France and Spain which was refused to be considered 82 to 24. Went off home this morning without giving notice to any body at his lodgings.— Mr: Rose’s Negotiation closed.

20. Heard Mr: Sayres this morning at Georgetown— Late there, having been too long detained at home, writing— The remainder of the day also, and Evening I was assiduously engaged, but did not get half through my work— Mr: Verplanck, a member of the House from New-York, told me there were recent accounts from England, with the Speech at the opening of Parliament.

21. In Senate I arrived late; having spent part of the morning in writing— Nearly the whole sitting was employed in Executive business, upon the nomination of William Hull, as Governor of the Michigan Territory— Mr: & Mrs: Boyd pass’d the Evening with us, and also Mr: L. Casamajor, who informed us that with Mr: Rose and his brother he was going to-morrow Evening to Alexandria, and thence in a Packet to Norfolk, where they were to embark immediately on board the Statira, upon their return to England.

22. Called this morning at the Office of the Treasury, and enquired of Mr: Sheldon whether any regulations had yet been made, respecting the permissions to be obtained from the President, for dispatching vessels in Ballast, to bring home property from abroad. he said the arrangement was making, but not yet accomplished— And that the applications were numerous. On my arrival in Senate I found the Message from the President had been received containing the copies of all the negotiations with France and England, for two or three years.— The papers are very voluminous— We read untill nearly four O’Clock, and adjourned, without doing any thing else— Spent the Evening with my wife, at Mr: Boyd’s.

23. Met Mr: Giles’s Committee on the Habeas Corpus, this morning at 10— We sat untill half past 11. discussing a bill, which the chairman had drawn; but we came to no conclusion; and are to meet again to-morrow morning— In Senate the reading of the papers was resumed and continued untill nearly 4 O’Clock—when after passing the militia-bill, without debate, we adjourned.— All the confidential papers were this day read— I spent the Evening at home very busily engaged.

24. Met the Habeas-Corpus Committee again this morning— It was agreed that the Chairman should report his Bill; with only my voice dissenting— My objection was to a section taking from the Supreme Court of the United States the power of issuing the writ— In Senate the reading of the papers was resumed and continued untill near 4. O’Clock— Evening at home—writing.

25. In Senate— Mr: Maclay offered a Resolution in Executive business, to ask for papers respecting Governor Hull; which after some debate on the form, was adopted— The reading of papers was resumed and continued untill past 3. P.M— Three other short messages were received from the President.— A Bill was pass’d to the third reading; and no other business done.— The Vice-President spoke with much indifference about the papers now reading, which he considered as of no consequence. Mr: Giles and Mr: Anderson were anxious to exclude from the publication, Mr: Monroe’s exposition of the rejected Treaty—written since his return home— Electioneering in every thing— I spent the Evening at home.

26. In Senate— The reading of the papers was continued and almost finished— The unratified Treaty and the whole correspondence respecting its negotiation has been read; including a letter from Mr: Monroe to the Secretary of State, written since his return home, to vindicate his own character from unjust imputations for signing the Treaty. There are only some old papers of 1804 left. In the Evening Mr: & Mrs: Boyd—Dr: Kirkpatrick, Mr: Verplanck & Dr: Woodhouse were here. I called this morning on Mr: Madison, to make some enquiries respecting impressments.

27. I went with Mrs: Hellen and the Ladies, and heard Mr M’Cormick at the Capitol. All the rest of the day I was engaged in writing— I was somewhat unwell last Night, and was also called up by the child— At the Capitol Mr: Gilman took me aside and shewed me a letter from Dr: Eustis, requesting that I would permit the publication of one of my last Letters to Mr: Jos: Hall—which without absolutely refusing, I declined— I mentioned to Mr: Gilman that I had a formal answer to Mr: Pickering’s letter, in preparation, address’d to H. G. Otis— That I had only to copy it; and that unless there was some peculiar reason for Eustis’s wishing that the letter to Hall should appear, I desired him to say that in a few days he would have a reason for my objection, which I believed would be satisfactory to him.

28. In Senate, we finished this day the reading of our papers; and also did a little other business— I called this morning at the Secretary of State’s Office, and returned him a newspaper which he had lent me on Saturday Morning— This morning and Evening I was steadily employed in writing, as I have been for several days.

29. The day was again absorbed excepting that part of it which I pass’d at the Capitol, in constant writing.— Mrs: Boyd dined with us, and Mr: Boyd was here in the Evening— There was little business done in Senate— Since the reading of the dispatches there appears a great listlessness upon subjects of minor importance.— After the adjournment I went for a short time into the house of Representatives— They were on the Post-Office Bill— It seems the President has given an extra-official hint, that he does not much apprehend War, and that the number of troops the House were raising would not all be wanted— So they have already reduced it from ten to six thousand.

30. Met at ten this Morning Mr: Giles’s Committee on the public contract bill— The members besides the Chairman, are Smith of Maryland, Thruston, Anderson and myself— We compared the Bill from the House and General Smith’s Amendment as proposed, with the English Statute of 22. George 3d. ch. 45. and finally agreed that the Chairman should draw a new bill, to be selected from them all— In Senate, Messages from the President were received, with further dispatches both from France and England, more menacing than any before received— The Court Martial-Bill, was considerably discussed, but postponed without any question taken. The nomination of Governor Hull was further considered, untill the adjournment. We all dined and spent most of the Evening at Mr: Boyd’s— I had forgotten my engagement there and came first home to dinner— Mr: Caldwell was at Mr: Boyd’s in the Evening— We were hastened home by a thunder-shower.

31. I finished my letter to H. G. Otis, for publication; and before I sent it away shewed it to Mr: Anderson, for his opinion whether there was in it any thing that ought to be struck out—in particular whether it treated my Colleague Mr: Pickering with sufficient delicacy. He returned it with commendation, and without suggesting any alteration— I enclosed it to W. S. Shaw with a request that he would get it printed immediately— I also wrote a few lines to H. G. Otis mentioning this letter to him, and my motives for sending it to Shaw for publication— In Senate, the nomination of Governor Hull was taken up, and his appointment confirmed 18 to 10. I was absent, at the time, and not very solicitous to be present— I had under the circumstances no small reluctance in voting either for or against him— My debenture Bill as amended by Mr: Bayard was discuss’d at the third reading, and, a motion for postponing it to the next Session of Congress was carried by yeas and nays 15 to 14.— Adjourned— Mr: Boyd and his wife pass’d the Evening with us. Mr: H. Erskine also spent part of it here— The step I have this day taken of publishing my letter to H. G. Otis, will be to me of the first importance— It will not be without importance to the Nation— It was taken from a strong sense of duty— That it will increase the difficulties and dangers of my situation I am fully aware— That it will bring upon me the fury of all my former enemies and a host of new ones, I perceive— I ask aid from above to support and pass through this ordeal— As my act has been deliberate, and will probably involve further controversy I pray for Intrepidity—Perseverance—Temperance—Justice, and Fortitude.

Day— Nearly the same as the two former months, and generally during my attendance upon Congress. The principal difference of this month is that I now rise earlier (about 6) and have employed more of morning & Eve: in writing.
